title-group.article-title: Past Victimizations and Dating Violence Perpetration in Adolescence
title-group.subtitle: The Mediating Role of Emotional Distress and Hostility

article-meta.aff: 1École de psychologie, Université Laval, Québec, Canada
2Département de sexologie, Université du Québec à Montréal, Montréal, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Francine Lavoie, École de psychologie, Université Laval, Pavillon Félix-Antoine Savard, 2325, rue des Bibliothèques, Local 1116, Québec (Québec), Canada, G1V 0A6 Email: Francine.lavoie@psy.ulaval.ca

fn.p: Sophie Boivin is a DPsy graduate from the École de psychologie at Université Laval, Québec. Her research interests are adolescence and dating violence. She works as a clinical psychologist in Québec (Québec), Canada. She can be reached at sophie_boivin@hotmail.com

Francine Lavoie is professor of community psychology in École de psychologie at Université Laval, Québec. Her research interests focus on prevention of dating violence and promotion of harmonious and equal relations during adolescence. She can be reached at Francine.Lavoie@psy.ulaval.ca

Martine Hébert is professor in the Département de sexologie at Université du Québec à Montréal. Her research interests focus on trajectories of resilience and revictimization in children, teenagers, and young adults’ victims of sexual abuse, and interpersonal partner violence. She can be reached at hebert.m@uqam.ca

Marie-Hélène Gagné is professor of community psychology in the École de psychologie at Université Laval, Québec. Her research interests focus on children and youth victimisation and child protection issues. She can be reached at Marie-Helene.Gagne@psy.ulaval.ca

abstract.p: This study aimed to understand the nature of the relationships between three forms of past victimizations (exposure to interparental violence in childhood, sexual harassment by peers since beginning high school, prior experience of dating violence), physical dating violence perpetration by adolescents, and anger-hostility and emotional distress. The sample was composed of 1,259 high school students aged between 14 and 19 years who answered self-report questionnaires. Mediation analyses were conducted according to Baron and Kenny’s approach. Logistic and linear regression analyses reveal that being victim of sexual harassment by peers and of dating violence are associated to physical dating violence perpetration via a partial mediating effect of hostility in girls. Contrary to results with girls, there is a complete mediating effect of emotional distress for boys. Results suggest that dating violence prevention and intervention strategies could be adapted according to gender and that sexual harassment should be addressed.

body.p: Dating violence in adolescence is a significant social and public health issue. Prevalence estimates regarding perpetration of physical dating violence vary between 11 % and 41% (Foshee & Matthew, 2007; Williams, Ghandour, & Kub, 2008). During the last decades, a number of risk factors associated to perpetration of dating violence were identified, namely, past victimizations. It remains important to understand the underlying processes by which adolescents of both genders who have been victimized in the past end up perpetrating violence; variables identified as possible mediators could be targeted in prevention and intervention efforts.

In the few available studies on perpetration during adolescence, a single form of victimization experience is usually explored as a risk factor, while the influence of diverse victimizations needs to be verified (Olsen, Parra, & Bennett, 2010). In the present study, three forms of past victimization are examined: exposure to interparental violence, sexual harassment by peers, and violence by a partner. Those experiences may lead in later romantic relationships to aggressive exchanges.

One of the most widely studied family precursors to dating violence is exposure to interparental violence (Stith et al., 2000); the intergenerational transmission of violence explanation posits that violence is learned in part through witnessing domestic violence. A relationship between witnessing domestic violence and perpetration of dating violence was found for boys (Lavoie & Vézina, 2002; O’Keeffe, 1997) or only for girls (Wolf & Foshee, 2003), while other studies stated that interparental violence was important for both genders (Foshee, Bauman, & Linder, 1999; Malik, Sorenson, & Aneshensel, 1997). However, some studies have failed to identify any link (Foshee, Linder, MacDougall, & Bangdiwala, 2001; Lavoie et al., 2002).

The other two types of victimizations, while important in the lives of adolescents, have only been rarely explored as predictors of dating violence perpetration. Violence experienced in the course of a current or past dating relationship was identified as one of the most important predictive factors of perpetration of physical dating violence by adolescents and of marital violence by adults (Malik et al., 1997; Stith, Smith, Penn, Ward, & Tritt, 2004). The influence of peers on perpetration of dating violence was mostly studied through the association with violent peers and less through experiences of victimization by peers (Olsen et al., 2010). Having been a victim of sexual harassment by peers was shown to relate to dating violence perpetration (Chiodo, Wolfe, Crooks, Hughes, & Jaffe, 2009; Gagné, Lavoie, & Hébert, 2004). An acquired anger expression style or emotional distress may explain the link between those past victimizations and dating violence perpetration and will thus be further analyzed.

sec.title: The Role of Anger-Hostility and Emotional Distress in Dating Violence Perpetration
sec.p: Depression was seen as predictive of physical violence with dating partners for adolescent girls (Capaldi & Crosby, 1997; Cleveland, Herrera, & Stuewig, 2003; McCloskey & Lichter, 2003). Hostility and antisocial behaviors were also associated to male adolescent perpetration of dating violence (Capaldi & Crosby, 1997; Lavoie et al., 2002) and more marginally to female perpetration (Schnurr & Lohman, 2008). The findings of low anger management skills or high hostility predicting male violence are consistent with past research and meta-analysis on young adults (Norlander & Eckhardt, 2005; Stith et al., 2004).

Empirical studies highlight the need to consider a possible mediating role of individual level variables, such as anger-hostility and emotional distress, between past victimizations and dating violence perpetration. The Impelling/Inhibiting model of Finkel (2007) proposes that those variables could play the role of violence impelling forces. Norlander and Eckhardt (2005) mention other theoretical models that relate prior victimization, anger, and later aggression. Adverse prior experiences might produce a tendency to experience situations egocentrically with a preoccupation with injustice and threats to the self. In such models, a triggering event in a recent relationship that is perceived as a loss or a threat to the self, even not necessarily aversive, automatically activates memories of prior violations, arousal of anger, and may result in aggression or flight. Anger expression was shown to explain the relationship between exposure to interparental conflict and dating violence perpetration (Clarey, Hokoda, & Ulloa, 2010; Foshee et al., 1999). When testing the influence of two different aggressive styles, Wolf and Foshee (2003) found that, for girls only, it was the direct aggressive destructive style that contributed while an indirect aggressive style did not. For Kinsfogel and Grych (2004), the effect of interparental conflict operated through boys’ tendency to have some difficulty in controlling anger. The role of emotional distress was underlined in a few studies. In a longitudinal design, McCloskey and Lichter (2003) documented that witnessing marital violence predicted depression, which later predicted dating violence for girls, but observed marital violence failed to predict aggression against a partner. O’Keeffe (1998) concluded that in boys who had witnessed high levels of interparental violence, low self-esteem discriminated those who inflicted violence to their dating partner from those who did not but it was not the case for girls. From this review, it can be seen that studies aiming to decipher the role of anger-hostility and emotional distress in perpetration of dating violence are inconclusive and limited to the context of prior witnessing of interparental violence.

sec.title: Past Victimizations in Relation to Anger-Hostility and Emotional Distress
sec.p: As studies of possible mediators, as those just described, are only beginning to be available, empirical reports documenting the link between victimization and the proposed explanatory factors will be discussed next. A meta-analysis indicates that children exposed to interparental physical violence (as victim or witness) report more negative affects such as emotional distress (Kitzmann, Gaylord, Holt, & Kenny, 2003). As for hostility, Somer and Braunstein (1999) mention in their literature review that witnessing interparental violence is related to anger and aggressiveness control.

Sexual harassment during adolescence seems to trigger various negative emotional outcomes in the victims, such as emotional distress and a lower self-esteem and more so in girls (Hand & Sanchez, 2000). A longitudinal study showed that being a victim of sexual harassment predicted depressive symptoms in girls, but not in boys (Goldstein, Malanchuk, Davis-Kean, & Eccles, 2007). Another longitudinal study concluded that boys as well as girls, victims of sexual harassment in Grade 9, later reported more emotional distress and more delinquency perpetration while girls reported severe rates of suicidal thoughts and self-cutting behaviors (Chiodo et al., 2009).

Violence experienced by boys in dating is associated with high levels of depression, anxiety, posttraumatic stress, suicide ideation (Ackard, Eisenberg, & Neumark-Sztainer, 2007; Callahan, Tolman, & Saunders, 2003; Coker et al., 2000), while in girls, such experiences are linked to depression (Ackard et al., 2007), posttraumatic stress and dissociation (Callahan et al., 2003), and suicidal attempts (Silverman, Raj, Mucci, & Hathaway, 2001). Some studies concluded that for both sexes, victimization is related to depression (Banyard, Cross, & Modecki, 2006; Roberts, Klein, & Fisher, 2003; Wolitzky-Taylor et al., 2008) and to suicidal attempts (Ackard et al., 2007). Hostility, on the other hand, was associated to dating violence victimization in adolescent girls (Tourigny, Lavoie, Vézina, & Pelletier, 2006). In general, feelings of rejection could prompt hostility (Romero-Canyas, Downey, Berenson, Ayduk, & Kang, 2010).

sec.title: The Current Study
sec.p: Past studies report that some teens who have witnessed interparental violence or experienced dating violence or sexual harassment might become abusive in their romantic relationships. We suggest that anger-hostility and emotional distress are two important variables that could play an important role in this process. Our research questions are twofold:

list-item.p: Research Question 1: Are experiences of prior victimization associated with high levels of anger-hostility and emotional distress?
Research Question 2: Do anger-hostility and emotional distress explain the perpetration of dating violence?

sec.p: As aggression in dating relationships is frequent in adolescence, it is important to document factors that intervention and prevention programs need to target to insure optimal effects.

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p: The data to be analyzed are from a study that evaluated the effectiveness of a prevention program called An awareness and prevention program for teens (16-17 years old) focusing on abuse in dating relationships and sexual harassment (Lavoie, Pacaud, Roy, & Lebossé, 2007). Two measurement periods (Time 1 and 2 or preprogram and postprogram testing) were combined for the measure on perpetration; for other variables, only one measurement period was used. The participants completed the self-reported measures in class under the supervision of research assistants. The design was cross-sectional. The 15 Quebec secondary schools involved were situated in urban, semiurban and rural areas and were of medium-low socioeconomic level (Québec Government, 2004). Laval University’s research ethics committee approved the study.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A total of 2,288 youth participated from the 2,723 invited, which represents 84% of the target sample. Among this number, only participants who dated a partner (one-night date or regular relationship) during the last 5 months (n = 1,347) were selected. The participants (n = 88) who did not complete the scales of violence perpetration, emotional distress, and hostility were excluded. No imputation for missing data was made. The final sample was composed of 751 girls (59.7%) and 508 boys (40.3%) aged between 14 and 19 years (M = 16.22, SD = 0.72). The majority of the adolescents (81.3%) were in Grade 11, the others in Grade 10. Moreover, 87.1% of the participants were of Québec or Canadian origin and 96.5% spoke French and 64.7% of the participants lived with their two parents.

sec.title: Dating violence perpetration
sec.p: The five items regarding perpetrated physical violence were adapted from the scale of Lavoie and Vézina (2002). The items are (a) throwing an object which could have harmed the partner; (b) grabbing; (c) pushing or shoving; (d) slapping; (e) harming with the fists, feet, an object, or a weapon. To exclude self-defense behaviors, a note indicated not to report acts made in such context. The proposed scale was 0 (never), 1 (once), 2 (twice), and 3 (3 times and more). At Time 1, the participants had to refer to the last 4 months and at Time 2, to the last 6 weeks. The respective alphas were .72 (Time 1) and .83 (Time 2). A score of 0 was given when there was no violence at Time 1 and Time 2; a score of 1 was assigned to participants who reported at least one act of violence at least one time.

sec.title: Exposure to interparental violence
sec.p: Questions on interparental violence were adapted from Institut de la statistique du Québec (Fortin, 2002) and dealt with witnessing psychological and physical violence between parents since childhood. Questions were “Did it ever happen that your father/mother insulted, said nasty things or demeaning remarks to your mother/father?” And “(. . .) has beaten up, hit or physically hurt your father/mother?” The scale was 0 (never), 1 (once), and 2 (3 times and more). The global score was obtained by adding the four items, for a range of score from 0 to 8. A Cronbach’s alpha of .72 was obtained.

sec.title: Sexual harassment by peers
sec.p: Sexual harassment by peers since being in high school was measured with a brief version of seven items of the Sexual Experiences Questionnaire for adults (Fitzgerald, Gelfand, & Drasgow, 1995), adapted and translated by Hébert, Lavoie, and Senécal (2000). Participants were asked whether someone, other than a boyfriend/girlfriend, had made crude sexual remarks, subtly bribed with reward for sexual favors, and so on. The proposed scale was 0 (never), 1 (once to twice), and 2 (3 times and more). The global score was calculated by adding the items, for a possible range of score from 0 to 14. The internal consistency was of .77.

sec.title: Prevalence of prior dating violence victimization
sec.p: The prevalence of violence experienced since they began dating was assessed with two questions: “Did someone you were dating or you had dated used physical violence toward you (slapping, shoving, hitting, etc.)?” and “Did someone (. . .) force you to engage in a sexual activity against your will?” The choice of answers was 1 (yes) or 2 (no). Instructions asked them to identify events occurring before Time 1. A dichotomous score of 0 (no form of violence) or 1 (presence of either type of violence) was used.

sec.title: Emotional distress
sec.p: Emotional distress was measured using the Kessler Psychological Distress Scale (K10; Kessler et al., 2002) as translated by Statistics Canada (2002). The K10 is composed of 10 items regarding depression (3), anxiety (2), motor agitation (2), fatigue (2) and the feeling of being worthless (1). The response scale had 5 anchoring points (1 = none of the time to 5 = all of the time). A global score was computed for a possible range of score from 10 to 50. For this sample, the K10 showed an internal consistency of .85, which is comparable to the result obtained by Kessler et al. (2002; α = .93).

sec.title: Hostility
sec.p: A translation of the Brief Anger-Aggression Questionnaire (Maiuro, Vitaliano, & Cahn, 1987) was used to measure hostility with 6 items: indirect hostility, irritability, negativism, resentment, verbal hostility, and assault—(i.e., When I really lose my temper, I am capable of hitting . . .).The proposed scale was 0 (never), 2 (sometimes), 3 (often) and 4 (very often). The global score was obtained by adding the items, with a range from 0 to 24. The internal consistency was of .76 for this sample, while Maiuro et al.’s (1987) was .82.

sec.title: Plan of Analysis
sec.p: To evaluate whether anger-hostility or emotional distress played a mediating role between past victimizations and dating violence perpetration, we verified if our data respected the Baron and Kenny’s (1986) conditions: (a) the independent variables (exposure to interparental violence, sexual harassment, and dating violence) have to significantly predict the dependent variable (perpetrated physical violence) (path c); (b) the independent variables have to significantly predict the mediator variables (emotional distress and hostility) (path a); and (c) the mediator variables have to significantly predict the dependent variable (path b). The addition of a mediator is expected to reduce (partial mediation) or eliminate (total mediation) the initial effect of an independent variable on the dependent variable (path c’). Sobel’s test (Preacher & Hayes, 2004) was used to determine if the changes were significantly different from zero. To do so, the unstandardized coefficients (B) and the standard error (SE) of paths a and b were used.

To test the mediation models, logistic (for dichotomous variables) and linear (for continuous variables) regressions were conducted separately for girls and boys. Logarithmic transformations were performed on the variables Exposure to Interparental Violence and Sexual Harassment to reduce the skewness of the responses following Tabachnick and Fidell’s (2007) recommendations. Distribution of other variables considered did not require transformations.

sec.title: Preliminary Analyses
sec.p: Correlational analyses are presented by gender in Table 1. Ethnicity and family structure are not associated with the physical violence perpetrated by boys and girls. All other variables are slightly, but significantly correlated in the expected direction for both genders. Only variables showing a significant relationship at alpha level of .01 with the dependent variable were retained in the mediation models.

caption.p: Intercorrelations Among Variables as a Function of Gender

fn.p: Note: Intercorrelations for female participants (n = 751) are presented above the diagonal, and intercorrelations for male participants (n = 508) are presented below the diagonal. Regular: Pearson’s r coefficient; italic: Phi (φ) coefficient.

sec.title: Profile of Current Dating Aggression and Victimization
sec.p: Girls (26.2%) are significantly more likely than boys (10.8%) to have perpetrated physical violence during the last 5 months, χ2(1, N = 1,259) = 44.92, p = .000. Significant differences in the prevalence rates of the acts of violence reported by gender are found for throwing an object (6.0% of girls vs. 1.6% of boys), pushing or shoving (15.6% vs. 5.7%), slapping (15.7% vs. 1.8%), and harming with the fists, and so on (4.1% vs. 1.2%). Of the 1,259 adolescents of the sample, 875 (69.5%) say that they have never suffered from or perpetrated physical violence to their partner in the last 5 months, whereas 171 (13.6%) report having experienced and also perpetrating physical violence (125 girls and 46 boys).1 A total of 81 youths (6.4%) report having been only a perpetrator (72 girls and 9 boys), while 132 (10.5%) disclose they were only a victim (49 girls and 83 boys) of physical violence.

Nearly half of the girls (46.9%) and nearly a third of the boys (31.1%) have witnessed verbal or physical interparental violence at least once during their life, χ2(1, N = 1,259) = 31.27, p = .000. As for sexual harassment by peers, 60.3% of the girls and 35.6% of the boys have been victims at least once since the beginning of high school, χ2(1, N = 1,259) = 73.89, p = .000. Finally, 20.2% of the girls and 8.5% of the boys, χ2(1, N = 1,259) = 32.10, p = .000, sustained physical or sexual violence perpetrated by a partner in the course of their life. Girls (M = 22.93, SD = 6.59) experience, on average, more emotional distress, than boys (M = 19.57, SD = 6.14); t(1,257) = 9.26, p = .000). They also have an average hostility level (M = 7.58, SD = 4.32) higher than boys (M = 6.98, SD = 4.54); t(1,257) = 2.32, p = .02.

sec.title: Mediation Analyses
sec.p: Linear regressions indicate that exposure to interparental violence, sexual harassment by peers, and prevalence of prior dating violence are significantly associated to high levels of emotional distress and hostility (see Tables 2-3, path a). In girls, the three forms of victimization explain 10.9% of variance in emotional distress, F(3, 747) = 31.72, p < .001, and 14.5% of the variance for hostility, F(3, 747) = 43.20, p < .001. In boys, victimization experiences account for 14.0% of the variance in emotional distress, F(3, 504) = 28.52, p < .001, and 8.1% of the variance for hostility, F(3, 504) = 15.90, p < .001.

Logistic regression analyses indicate that only sexual harassment (OR = 3.40) and prior sustained dating violence (OR = 2.51) are associated with the perpetration of physical violence by girls (see Table 2, path c). In boys, sexual harassment (OR = 3.52) and prior sustained dating violence (OR = 2.27) are also the only variables related to perpetrated physical violence (see Table 3, path c). By controlling the independent variables, the logistic regression analyses reveal that emotional distress (OR = 1.06) is related to the physical violence perpetrated by boys, whereas hostility (OR = 1.10) is associated with the physical violence perpetrated by girls (see Tables 2-3, path b).

caption.p: Linear and Logistic Regression Analyses for Girls’ Dating Violence Perpetration (N = 751)

fn.p: Note: Path c: Independent variables as predictors of perpetrated violence. Path a: Independent variables as predictors of the mediators. Path b: Mediators as predictors of the perpetrated violence, by controlling the independent variables. Path c’: Effect of the independent variables on the perpetrated violence, by controlling for the mediators.

caption.p: Linear and Logistic Regression Analyses for Boys’ Dating Violence Perpetration (N = 508)

fn.p: Note: Path c: Independent variables as predictors of perpetrated violence. Path a: Independent variables as predictors of the mediators. Path b: Mediators as predictors of the perpetrated violence, by controlling the independent variables. Path c’: Effect of the independent variables on the perpetrated violence, by controlling for the mediators.

sec.p: Since exposure to interparental violence is not significantly associated with physical violence, the mediating effect of emotional distress and hostility could not be verified in that case. The results reveal that for girls the insertion of hostility (see Table 2, path c’) decreases the effect of sustained sexual harassment (from B = 1.22 to 0.95, p < .001) and the effect of prior sustained dating violence (from B = 0.92 to 0.85, p < .01) on the perpetration of physical violence (see Figure 1). In boys, a complete mediation through emotional distress is found for the same model (see Table 3, path c’). The insertion of emotional distress eliminates the effect of sexual harassment (from B = 1.26 to 0.98, p < .05) and the effect of prior sustained dating violence (from B = 0.82 to 0.65, p < .05) on perpetration of physical violence (see Figure 2).

caption.p: Mediation model for girls’ dating violence
Mediation model for boys’ dating violence

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, emotional distress and hostility were examined in a nonclinical sample of adolescents as the mediators of the associations between three forms of victimization and physical dating violence perpetration. It is one of the first studies testing a mediation model when considering past dating victimization and peer sexual harassment. For both genders, it seems that a culture of violence or a constellation of violence across different ecologies is found as suggested by Olsen et al. (2010). Prior experiences of peer violence and of dating violence are related to perpetration of violence.

The results present a clear distinction between girls and boys regarding the explanatory factors linked to perpetration of physical dating violence. For girls, hostility acts as partial mediator for sustained sexual harassment by peers and for past sustained dating violence. These results suggest that the more the girls have experienced these two forms of victimization, the more they are likely to present a high level of hostility and this is associated with inflicting physical violence to their partner. It was documented in previous studies that, for girls, sexual harassment places substantial limitations to their life such as interference with studies, restriction of social network, and that they become more involved in violent delinquency and substance use, all factors that may explain their hostility level (Chiodo et al., 2009; Hand & Sanchez, 2000). On one hand, hostility may be linked to an adaptive response to some situations in the life of these young girls by enabling them to protect themselves from a real threat. The victims of dating violence and of sexual harassment who report feelings of anger, impatience, and dissatisfaction toward life might be, on the other hand, more likely to develop conflicting social relationships and also to interpret neutral events in a negative way because they perceive them, due to their prior experiences, as interpersonal threats or rejection. Dating violence might thus be perpetrated by girls in various situations, two of which were documented in a qualitative study (Foshee, Bauman, Linder, Rice, & Wilcher, 2007): one as a protective measure or reactive measure following aggression initiated by the partner (ongoing patriarchal terrorism, rape), one as an offensive act toward a nonphysically violent partner (as a reaction of anger related to jealousy or as a message to stop drinking, flirting, etc.). Hostile girls could accept more easily violence as a self defense measure and perceive violence as an instrument to gain their way in an argument with a partner (Leisring, 2009). In the future, we need to understand more when a girl with anger and hostility feelings might escalate to partner violence. It remains to clarify if inabilities with regulation of strong emotions such as hostility or anger may be at play or some learned aggressive scripts or a cumulative vulnerability leading to choose a violent partner.

For boys, emotional distress acts as a complete mediator between prior sustained sexual harassment by peers and the perpetration of physical violence as well as between prior sustained dating violence and the perpetration of physical violence. These results suggest that emotional distress on its own term seems to be sufficient, considering the variables studied in the model, to perpetrate physical violence. Our results concur with data showing an association of perpetration by males with mood disorders and anxiety linked to low self-worth, perceived lack of control, anxiety about relationships, and perception of a less favorable power balance in the relationship (Giordano, Soto, Manning, & Longmore, 2010; Grych & Kinsfogel, 2010; Kessler, Molnar, Feurer, & Appelbaum, 2001). Our measure of distress included not only depression items but also anxiety items, which may explain our results. Also, distress might be the expression of specific deficits in interpersonal skills (e.g., poor problem-solving strategies, lack of empathy, inappropriate communication skills), which increase the probability that a youth experiences conflicts and uses coercive behaviors with intimates (Keenan-Miller, Hammen, & Brennan, 2007; Marcus, 2007). In interviews by Foshee et al. (2007), boys explained their dating violence as a tool to stop escalation by their partner, which could suggest that for some boys it is rather a defensive measure in a context of a history of violence. A lack of skills to disengage from a violent relationship could thus also be at stake.

As the relations were not significant, the contribution of witnessing interparental violence could not be verified in this nonclinical sample. Unlike other studies (Foshee et al., 1999; Malik et al., 1997; McCloskey & Lichter, 2003), exposure to interparental violence was not associated with perpetration of physical violence. However, contrary to this present study, those earlier surveys measured physical or sexual violence perpetrated between the parents, which could have more damaging repercussions on youths as compared to psychological violence that we included in our measure. To evaluate this possibility, we conducted an a posteriori analysis, keeping only the exposure to interparental physical violence; but no significant relationship was revealed. It seems that for this nonclinical sample of 16 years old of medium-low socioeconomic level, dating violence is more likely to be related to victimizations by peers directly experienced during adolescence.

The important overlap of current experiences of dating violence and of perpetration of dating violence influences the interpretation of the results. Indeed, nearly 68% (171/252) of the youth who perpetrated physical violence toward their partner during the last 5 months have also been victims of such violence. The effect of the mediators must therefore be understood within a dynamic of mutual violence rather than within an aggressor–victim relationship, since emotional distress and hostility do not act as mediators in the case of “pure” aggressors, as was verified in a post hoc study.2

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations
sec.p: One of the strength of the present research is the distinct analyses of boys and girls and the consideration of three forms of victimization. The cross-sectional design precludes any conclusions about causality even if retrospective information was solicited. There is a possibility that the mediators could co-occur with or be a consequence of the perpetrated violence. Indeed depression could be a consequence of violence perpetration. Victims of prior dating violence may have been victimized recently and by the same partner they are still dating; such information was not available. Measurement problems of dating violence also influence our data, such as underreporting of violence by boys and inclusion of acts of self-defense even when instructions ask not to do it (Foshee et al., 2007). Finally, sexual harassment was not mediated by emotional distress nor associated to perpetration by boys. One explanation, for boys, may be that our measure did not include the behavior judged the most disrupting by them, being called gay (Hand & Sanchez, 2000), so it precludes a definitive conclusion on the effect of sexual harassment in our mediation model.

sec.title: Implications
sec.p: Victimization surveys and police reports clearly reveal that female victimization represents the more pressing social problem. Nevertheless, this study stresses the importance of explicitly including content on female perpetration of physical violence as well as on male perpetration and of introducing more gender-specific interventions into prevention programs. Emotional distress, that is depression and anxiety, would be an important element to consider with boys, whereas a particular attention should be given to the intolerance to frustration and hostility in girls while not neglecting the past circumstances that led them to develop this hostility. We should be cautious to not merely attribute the cause of violence to anger or depression and overlook other explanations such as social norms, past history, and so on. In our study, girls were indeed significantly more likely to report experiencing all forms of victimizations.

Teaching skills on conflict resolution and emotional regulation in dating or in peer relationships are important to consider in prevention and intervention programs. First-line practitioners need to be vigilant and assess the possible experiences of hostile or depressed adolescents with current dating victimization and aggression. Such inquiries could be more difficult with boys as they may prefer not to talk about inflicted or sustained violence to avoid stigmatization or social judgment (Price, Byers, & Dating Violence Research Team, 1999). It may be useful to offer them an anonymous hotline where they could find support. Such hotline services should be able to offer support to not only the victims but also the youths wanting to talk about the challenges they faced in romantic relationships and their possible aggressive behaviors. Regarding intervention with girls, it might be important to explore, with teenage girls who were sexually harassed, what they came to learn and feel from such experiences where they were treated as a sexual object usually by young boys. Some sexual demands by their actual romantic partner could indeed be perceived or interpreted as exploitative or demonstrating a certain lack of respect and be met with hostility or anxiety rather than with assertive behaviors. As mentioned by Downey, Bonica, and Rincón (1999), adolescents girls who have developed expectations of rejection because of past experiences may be more sensitive to rejection by a partner, be it in a conflict or in situations perceived as demonstrating lack of attention and may respond by hostile behaviors. Thus the authors conclude that breaking the cycle of rejection is important and that experiences of positive romantic relationships may indeed provide adolescents of both genders with opportunities for change. For boys and girls, discussion about how to break up relationships, consideration of others’ feelings, and possible reactions to feelings of rejection could be added to prevention programs. Furthermore, variables other than anger and emotional distress need to be studied before developing specific treatments. Meanwhile, Marcus (2007) describes a few avenues to consider around anger or mood-related problems as risk factors for aggression. In particular, small group programs, such as anger management training, might help adolescents to learn assertive instead of aggressive responses and to cope with the stress of being rejected and of having a negative self-concept and therapies, such as Emotion Focused Therapy, which might help not only to lessen anger but also to understand it as covering other feelings such as humiliation, are discussed by the author. Their efficiency to prevent perpetration of dating violence remains to be confirmed.

As for future research, we need to understand the different functions of aggression for boys and girls and also to clarify who initiated the physical aggression. This study finally reminds us of the importance of giving more consideration to sexual harassment as a factor associated to dating violence perpetration. Not only the victims suffer but also the general school climate created by the presence of sexual harassment is known to affect all girls and boys.

fn.p: This publication is based on the DPsy dissertation of S. Boivin.
The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

The authors disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: The original survey was partially funded through the Government of Canada’s National prevention Centre, in collaboration with the Ministère de la Sécurité Publique du Québec. The opinions expressed in this document do not reflect the official policies of the Government of Canada or the Ministère de la Sécurité Publique du Québec. It was also funded by the Fonds québécois de la recherche sur la société et la culture.

For descriptive purposes, an adaptation of the items of Lavoie and Vézina (2002) was used to measure current victimization by a partner. This should not be confused with the variable prevalence of dating violence victimization.

Mediation analyses were conducted by excluding the youth who were in a dynamic of mutual violence (n = 171). The results indicate that only sexual harassment by peers (OR = 1.44, p = .001) is related to the physical violence perpetrated by girls (N = 626), whereas no past victimization is associated with physical violence perpetrated by boys (N = 462). In girls, emotional distress and hostility do not act as mediators.
